page.title: 11 Sawmill. Harlestone Heath
page.content: The mill, built by Lord Spencer in the 1900's covers an area of about three acres. It provides jobs for fourteen, not including the lorry crivers. Health and Safety Inspectors check the mill about twice a year. There are four saws including a very big one that cuts tree trunks into strips. They cut seven types of softwoods and also buy timber from other countries. The trees are allowed to grow to about five metres before felling and a gap of four metres is left between each tree. Some trees die off because of disease. The tree trunks are stored in the yard at the back of the mill. The sawdust is sold to butchers and the stumps are used for firewood. The mill area abounds in large African ants first introduced on the estate for game hunting.
